snippet.textDisplay: How does Corona handle surfaces that become more sharply reflective at glancing angles? In the real world a material may be pretty rough at low incidence angles, but when you look down the length of the object it becomes more mirror like. TheaRender accounts for this (as a material option). So it's not just that the fresnel effect should decrease with increasing roughness, but alternatively a surface's roughness should INCREASE at glancing angles.
snippet.textOriginal: How does Corona handle surfaces that become more sharply reflective at glancing angles? In the real world a material may be pretty rough at low incidence angles, but when you look down the length of the object it becomes more mirror like. TheaRender accounts for this (as a material option). So it's not just that the fresnel effect should decrease with increasing roughness, but alternatively a surface's roughness should INCREASE at glancing angles.

snippet.textDisplay: How does the blur setting effect a map? In these tutorials, I often see the blur turned down to something like .01
snippet.textOriginal: How does the blur setting effect a map? In these tutorials, I often see the blur turned down to something like .01

snippet.textDisplay: It softens the map (rather like a subtle blur in Photoshop or similar), reducing it to .01 may be useful for some things where a sharper result is needed (in general, the slight blur added in the default is useful for prevent artifacts or oversharpening, but for some cases it can be useful to lower the value). Hope this helps! Tom
snippet.textOriginal: It softens the map (rather like a subtle blur in Photoshop or similar), reducing it to .01 may be useful for some things where a sharper result is needed (in general, the slight blur added in the default is useful for prevent artifacts or oversharpening, but for some cases it can be useful to lower the value). Hope this helps! Tom

snippet.textDisplay: Would a rule of thumb to be first to dial in your material's glossiness at the standard IOR...let's say 1.6 for wood. Then once that looks correct, you can begin to adjust the IOR setting (if needed) to compensate for any more or less reflections you'd like. The fact that adjusting the IOR effects the glossiness and level of reflectivity is interesting.
snippet.textOriginal: Would a rule of thumb to be first to dial in your material's glossiness at the standard IOR...let's say 1.6 for wood. Then once that looks correct, you can begin to adjust the IOR setting (if needed) to compensate for any more or less reflections you'd like. The fact that adjusting the IOR effects the glossiness and level of reflectivity is interesting.

snippet.textDisplay: There are more videos to come in the Phys Mat series, and then there will be other future videos on more specific materials, so keep an eye out for those over time! On the Material Library, it will in fact be removed and all materials added to Cosmos, and the current plan would be for those to come in as Corona Physical Material. Of course, that is a plan, and we'll have to wait and see how the implementation actually goes. Thanks! Tom
snippet.textOriginal: There are more videos to come in the Phys Mat series, and then there will be other future videos on more specific materials, so keep an eye out for those over time! On the Material Library, it will in fact be removed and all materials added to Cosmos, and the current plan would be for those to come in as Corona Physical Material. Of course, that is a plan, and we'll have to wait and see how the implementation actually goes. Thanks! Tom

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi! Looks like a lot of feedback on tools, etc. - please can you post that over on our forums? Developers and support can't monitor YouTube comments so would not see your feedback and suggestions here for possible improvements to PBR, so the forums would be the place to share those: https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php?board=5.0

(Also, do keep in mind that PBR in this tutorial is now very different in Corona 7 onward, thanks to the new Physical Material, which may have addressed some of your suggested improvements !) Thanks! Tom

snippet.textDisplay:
Not sure what is meant by "smoothness" which is not a feature of the material (smoothing is taken care of by the host application). Sounds like your questions are quite involved, and best thing to do is ask over on the forums where images can be shared to show what you mean, etc. https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php for that.

As for the dislikes, "You can please some of the people some of the time..." as the saying goes, nothing ever meets the needs of everyone, though we try our best! And if a video doesn't cover everything, that's what our support team and community is for, over on the forums :) Thanks!
snippet.textOriginal:
Not sure what is meant by "smoothness" which is not a feature of the material (smoothing is taken care of by the host application). Sounds like your questions are quite involved, and best thing to do is ask over on the forums where images can be shared to show what you mean, etc. https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php for that.

As for the dislikes, "You can please some of the people some of the time..." as the saying goes, nothing ever meets the needs of everyone, though we try our best! And if a video doesn't cover everything, that's what our support team and community is for, over on the forums :) Thanks!

snippet.textDisplay: Sorry, not sure what you mean "where is PBR files"? Due to licensing restrictions on texture maps, objects, etc. we don't share scenes with our tutorials, but that should be fine as we explain everything in such a way that you can follow along with your own texture maps and assets that you have on hand. (Also as a note, this tutorial is out of date now anyway for Corona 7 and onward, as we have a new Physical Material in there). Thanks! Tom
snippet.textOriginal: Sorry, not sure what you mean "where is PBR files"? Due to licensing restrictions on texture maps, objects, etc. we don't share scenes with our tutorials, but that should be fine as we explain everything in such a way that you can follow along with your own texture maps and assets that you have on hand. (Also as a note, this tutorial is out of date now anyway for Corona 7 and onward, as we have a new Physical Material in there). Thanks! Tom
